posts.name: mahim
posts.cooked:
I really appreciate the fact that we are moving towards functional programming with commands, and having specific classes for instances where you’d want to just pass in method references for actions you want to do instead of writing fully blown classes. As well as different classes that get different types of commands like InstantCommand , RunCommand , StartEndCommand .

But lets say you want a command that runs as long as a button is pressed and do an action when its stopped you either have to make a FunctionalCommand where it can look something like this:

or simply chaining and andThen() after a RunCommand . But what if you need to define an isFinished logic if you want the command to end early? Theres no predefined class where you just pass in method references for execute, isFinished, and end. You could just use the FunctionalCommand and leave the init: () -> {} to do nothing. But personally I believe it can get confusing, or cumbersome to always having to define each part of a Command when you’re not even using it.

I think it would be really helpful if we have a CommandBuilder class where we can pass in the methods you want to reference, and the command builder will build a command with only those parts and not having to pass in a “do nothing” section. It can look something like this:

I think this design pattern can be beneficial in some instances than using a FunctionalCommand:

you can define isFinished() with a boolean OR a BooleanSupplier while you still have to pass () -> false if you use FunctionalCommand .

you can define isFinished() with a boolean OR a BooleanSupplier while you still have to pass () -> false if you use FunctionalCommand .

same with end() you can pass in a Consumer<Boolean> or a Runnable instead of having to ignore the boolean if you just want to pass an action where it doesn’t matter if the command was interrupted or not.

same with end() you can pass in a Consumer<Boolean> or a Runnable instead of having to ignore the boolean if you just want to pass an action where it doesn’t matter if the command was interrupted or not.

this way you don’t have to define sections of the command you want to leave empty. You are forced to define every part in a FunctionalCommand . The CommandBuilder object can start off with the init & exec to do nothing, isFinished as returning true, and end to do nothing unless you change it by using the chain methods.

this way you don’t have to define sections of the command you want to leave empty. You are forced to define every part in a FunctionalCommand . The CommandBuilder object can start off with the init & exec to do nothing, isFinished as returning true, and end to do nothing unless you change it by using the chain methods.

it is easier to read. having to pass in every part of the command through the constructor can be confusing, and you have to remember which order to put them in. But using a builder pattern you can pass them however you want, and easier to understand which parts you’re adding in without fancy intellisense.

it is easier to read. having to pass in every part of the command through the constructor can be confusing, and you have to remember which order to put them in. But using a builder pattern you can pass them however you want, and easier to understand which parts you’re adding in without fancy intellisense.

and the inside can look something like this:

Do you guys think this would be something useful?

I recommend looking at the new command factories (some in the Commands utility class). Command composition is somewhat similar to what you’re suggesting, and is far more powerful and flexible.

With the building blocks of runOnce() (aka InstantCommand) and run() (aka RunCommand), combined with decorators such as until() , finallyDo() , andThen , etc., you can really do anything via command compositions.

Some recommended reads:

Included building-block commands (this includes FunctionalCommand, among others): Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

API docs of factories in Commands : Commands (WPILib API 2023.3.2)

Command compositions: Command Compositions — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Mahim:

But lets say you want a command that runs as long as a button is pressed and do an action when its stopped

If I understood your post correctly, something like that should do it

posts.name: mahim
posts.cooked:
I definitely missed this in the new update, I just had a look and that solves everything I could think of with command compositions.

realistically I’m assuming there’s no big difference if I decorate a RunCommand with a startsWith() which gives a SequentialCommand instead of just making a single command with an initialize() and execute() ? since one is basically scheduling two commands back to back and instead of a single command.

posts.name: mahim
posts.cooked: That definitely is a way to do it. This was just a hypothetical to see if that can be better solved by a command rather than listeners on Triggers

It’s not scheduling two separate commands. Command compositions are opaque to the scheduler, and are seen as one command. So, no, there wouldn’t be a significant difference between a single command with init and exe vs a sequential composition.

Fletch1373:

Mahim:

But lets say you want a command that runs as long as a button is pressed and do an action when its stopped

You could also do this:

(add an until in there if you want the command to be able to finish itself)
